bestBHT.bht: On the holy mount, Peter, James, and John heard a voice from heaven that bore witness to the divinity of Jesus. This voice, seen as a manifestation of Christ's divine glory, was heard and witnessed by the apostles. The sanctity of the mount, like the ground where God appeared to Moses, added to its significance. This event was an earnest display of the power in which Christ would return, teaching the importance of reverently receiving God and preparing for holiness in His presence.

Henry Alford: And this voice we (Apostles: Peter, James, and John) heard borne from heaven.
We heard it borne, witnessed its coming, from heaven.
The place whereon Moses stood is said, in Exodus iii. 5, to be holy ground.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Transfiguration mount came to be regarded, on account of the manifestation of Christ's divine glory there.
We, James and John, as well as myself.
Albert Barnes: And this voice which came from heaven we heard - To wit, Peter, and James, and John.
When we were with him in the holy mount - Called 'holy' on account of the extraordinary manifestation of the Redeemer's glory there.
It is not certainly known what mountain this was, but it has commonly been supposed to be Mount Tabor.
Marvin Vincent: Voice [φωνην] . Note the same word in the account of Pentecost (Acts 2:6), where the A. V. obscures the meaning by rendering, when this was noised abroad; whereas it should be when this voice was heard."
Which came [ενεχθεισαν] . Lit., having been born. See on ver. 17. Rev., This voice we ourselves [ημεις, ωε, εμπηατιχ] heard come (better, born) out of heaven."
Of all places to which special sanctity would be ascribed by Christ 's followers, surely that would be the first to be so marked where the most solemn testimony was given to the divinity of Jesus.
John Calvin: He calls it the holy mount, for the same reason that the ground was called holy where God appeared to Moses.
Wherever the Lord comes, as he is the fountain of all holiness, he makes holy all things by the odor of his presence.
We are taught, not only to receive God reverently wherever he shows himself, but also to prepare ourselves for holiness, as soon as he comes nigh us.
Philip Schaff: It came immediately from heaven. It was reported, too, by those who were present with Christ Himself on the occasion, and were both eyewitnesses and ear-witnesses of what took place.
The sacred associations now connected with it, and the fact that it had been the scene of a manifestation of Divinity, had made it 'holy' ground.
In that he recognised an earnest of the power in which Christ was to return.
Archibald T. Robertson: This voice (ταυτην την φωνην). The one referred to.
In the holy mount (εν τω αγιω ορε). Made holy by the majestic glory.
John Gill: And this voice, which came from heaven, we heard...
when we were with him; and saw his glory, and the glory of Moses and Elias...
John Wesley: And we — Peter, James, and John. St. John was still alive.
Being with him in the holy mount — Made so by that glorious manifestation, as mount Horeb was of old, Exodus 3:4,5.
